name: Avoid cross-site scripting (persistent)
associatedValueName: Call stack from user input source down to the target method
description:
This quality rule identifies code paths where user-controllable input is stored in persistent data stores and later retrieved and rendered to users' browsers without proper sanitization or encoding. The rule specifically targets stored (persistent) cross-site scripting vulnerabilities, where malicious scripts are persisted on the server and executed whenever the contaminated data is displayed, potentially affecting multiple users over time.
Unlike reflected XSS where the attack affects a single user immediately, stored XSS poses a higher risk as the malicious payload persists and can impact all users who view the contaminated data, particularly when displayed in administrative interfaces, user profiles, comments sections, or other shared content areas.
output:
List all methods that make resource calls forged by database content

It provides the following information:
 - Method full name
 - Call stack from database source down to the target method.
rationale:
It creates severe security risks.
Consequences:
-Session hijacking: attackers can steal authentication cookies and impersonate users
-Data theft: sensitive information displayed on the page can be extracted and sent to malicious servers
-Defacement: page content can be modified to display fraudulent information
-Credential harvesting: fake login forms can be injected to capture user credentials
-Malware distribution: users can be redirected to malicious websites or prompted to download malware
-etc.
The vulnerability is particularly dangerous because the malicious code executes with the same privileges as the legitimate website, bypassing browser security controls.

remediation:
To prevent reflected XSS vulnerabilities, implement defense-in-depth strategies:
Primary Defense - Output Encoding:
-Apply context-appropriate encoding to all user data before outputting to HTML
-Use HTML entity encoding for HTML content
-Use JavaScript encoding for JavaScript contexts
-Use URL encoding for URL parameters
Framework-Specific Recommendations:
-Use built-in security features provided by your web framework
-Leverage templating engines with automatic escaping
-Avoid direct string concatenation for HTML generation
alternativeName: Ensure you don't use user input without validation
